sp.l: Of England and a most accomplished lady,
So modest that men's eyes are frighted at her,Enter a boy.
And such a noble carriage. How now sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, the great English lady.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What of her, sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Has newly left her coach, and coming this way,
Where you may see her plain: monsieur Pinac,
The only man that leads her.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: He is much honoured;
Would I had such a favour: now vex ladies,
Envy, and vex, and rail.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Ye are short of us, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Bless your fair fortune, sir.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I nobly thank ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is she married, friend?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A goodly lady;
A sweet and delicate aspect: mark, mark, and wonder.
Hast thou any hope of her?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: A little.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Follow close then:
Lose not that hope.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: To you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Gentle lady.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She is fair indeed.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: I have seen a fairer, yet
She is well.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Her clothes sit handsome too.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: She dresses prettily.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And by my faith she is rich; she looks still sweeter.
A well-bred woman, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Do you hear, sir;
May I crave this gentlewoman's name?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Mariana, lady.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I will not say I owe ye a quarrel monsieur
For making me your stale: a noble gentleman
Would have had more courtesy; at least, more faith,
Then to turn of his mistress at first trial:
You know not what respect I might have showed ye;
I find ye have worth.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I cannot stay to answer ye;
Ye see my charge: I am beholding to ye
For all your merry tricks ye put upon me,
Your bobs, and base accounts: I came to love ye,
To woo ye, and to serve ye; I am much indebted to ye
For dancing me off my legs; and then for walking me;
For telling me strange tales I never heard of,
More to abuse me; for mistaking me,
When ye both know I was a gentleman,
And one deserved as rich a match as you are.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Be not so bitter, sir.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: You see this lady:
She is young enough, and fair enough to please me,
A woman of a loving mind, a quit,
And one that weighs the worth of him that loves her,
I am content with this, and bless my fortune,
Your curious wits, and beauties.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Faith see me once more.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I dare not trouble ye.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: May I speak to your lady?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I pray ye content yourself: I know ye are bitter,
And in your bitterness, ye may abuse her;
Which if she comes to know, (For she understands ye not)
It may breed such a quarrel to your kindred,
And such an indiscretion fling on you too;
For she is nobly friended.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I could eat her.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Rest as ye are, a modest noble gentlewoman,
And afford your honest neighbours some of your prayers.Ex

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What think you now?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Faith she's a pretty whiting;
She has got a pretty catch too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You are angry;
Monstrous angry now; grievously angry;
And the pretty heart does swell now.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: No in troth, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And it will cry anon; a pox upon it:
And it will curse itself: and eat no meat, lady;
And it will fight.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Indeed you are mistaken;
It will be very merry.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why, sir, do you think
There are no more men living, nor no handsomer
Than he, or you; by this light there be ten thousand
Ten thousand thousand: comfort yourself, dear monsieur,
Faces, and bodies, wits, and all abiliments
There are so many we regard 'em not.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That such a noble lady, I could burst now.
So far above such trifles.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You did laugh at me,
And I know why ye laughed.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: I pray ye be satisfied;
If we did laugh, we had some private reason,
And not at you.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: Alas, we know you not, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll make you know me; set your faces soberly;
Stand this way, and look sad; I'll be no may-game;
Sadder; demurer yet.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What's the matter?
What ails this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Go off now backward, that I may behold ye;
And not a simper on you lives.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: He's mad sure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Do you observe me too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I may look on ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why do you grin? I know your mind.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You do not.
You are strangely humorous: is there no mirth, nor pleasure,
But you must be the object?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mark, and observe me;
Wherever I am named;
The very word shall raise a general sadness,
For the disgrace this scurvy woman did me;
This proud pert thing; take heed ye laugh not at me;
Provoke me not, take heed.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I would fain please ye;
Do any thing to keep ye quiet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hear me,
Till I receive a satisfaction
Equal to the disgrace, and scorn ye gave me:
Ye are a wretched woman; till thou wooest me,
And I scorn thee as much, as, seriously,
Gear, and abuse thee; ask what Gill thou art;
Or any baser name; I will proclaim thee;
I will so sing thy virtue; so bepaint thee,

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Nay, good sir, be more modest.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Do you laugh again?
Because ye are a woman ye are lawless,
And out of compass of an honest anger.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Good sir, have a better belief of me.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Away dear sister. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is not this better now, this seeming madness,
Then falling out with your friends.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have I not frighted her?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Into her right wits, I warrant thee: follow this humour,
And thou shalt see how prosperously 'twil guide thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am glad I have found a way to woo yet, I was afraid once
I never should have made a civil suitor.
Well, I'll about it still. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Do, do, and prosper.
What sport do I make with these fools? What pleasure
Feeds me, and fats my sides at their poor innocence? Enter Leverduce daes Lugier, Mr. Illiard.
Wooing and wiving, hang it: give me mirth,
Witty and dainty mirth: I shall grow in love sure
With mine own happy head. Who's this? To me, sir?
What youth is this?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Yes, sir, I would speak with you,
If your name be monsieur Mirabel.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ye have hit it:
Your business, I beseech ye.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: This it is, sir.
There is a gentlewoman hath long time affected ye,
And loved ye dear.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Turn over, and end that story,
'Tis long enough: I have no faith in women, sir.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: It seems so, sir: I do not come to woo for her,
Or sing her praises, though she well deserve 'em.
I come to tell ye, ye have been cruel to her,
Unkind and cruel, falser of faith, and careless,
Taking more pleasure in abusing her,
Wresting her honour to your wild disposes,
Then noble in requiting her affection.
Which, as ye are a man, I must desire ye
(A gentleman of rank) not to persist in,
No more to load her fair name with your injuries.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, I beseech ye, sir?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Good sir, I'll tell ye.
And I'll be short: I'll tell ye, because I love ye,
Because I would have you shun the shame may follow,
There is a noble man, new come to town, sir,
A noble and a great man that affects her,
A countryman of mine, a brave Sav yan,
Nephew to th'duke, and so much honours her,
That 'twill be dangerous to pursue your old way,
To touch at any thing concerns her honour,
Believe, most dangerous: her name is Oriana,
And this great man will marry her: take heed, sir;
For howsoe'er her brother, a staid gentleman,
Lets things pass upon better hopes, this lord, sir,
Is of that fiery, and that poignant metal,
(Especially provoked on by affection)
That 'twill be hard: but you are wise.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A lord, sir?

sp.speaker: Lev.
sp.l: Yes, and a noble lord.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Send her good fortune.
This will not stir her lord; a baroness,
Say ye so; say ye so: by'r lady, a brave title;
Top, and top gallant now; save her great ladyship.
I was a poor servant of hers, I must confess, sir,
And in those days, I thought I might be jovy,
And make a little bold to call into her:
But basto, now; I know my rules and distance;
Yet, if she want an usher; such an implement;
One that is thoroughly paced; a clean made gentleman;
Can hold a hanging up; with approbation
Plant his hat formally, and wait with patience
I do beseech you, sir.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Sir, leave your scoffing;
And as ye are a gentleman, deal fairly:
I have given ye a friend's council, so I'll leave ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: But hark ye, hark ye, sir; is't possible
I may believe what you say?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: You may choose, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No baits? No fishhooks, sir? No gins? No nooses?
No pitfalls to catch puppies?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: I tell ye certain;
You may believe; if not, stand to the danger. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: A lord of Sav y says he? The Duke's nephew?
A man so mighty? By 'Lady a fair marriage;
By my faith, a handsome fortune: I must leave prating;
For to confess the truth, I have abused her,
For which I should be sorry; but that will seem scurvy;
I must confess, she was ever since I knew her
As modest, as she was fair: I am sure she loved me;
Her means good; and her breeding excellent;
And for my sake she has refused fair matches:
I may play the fool finely. Stay who are these? Enter De-gard, Oriana, and attendants.
'Tis she, I am sure; and that the lord it should seem,
He carries a fair port; is a handsome man too:
I do begin to feel, I am a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Good my lord, choose a nobler: for I know
I am so far below your rank and honour,
That what ye can say this way, I must credit,
But spoken to beget yourself sport: alas, sir,
I am so far off, from deserving you,
My beauty so unfit for your affection,
That I am grown the scorn of common railers,
Of such injurious things, that when they cannot
Reach at my person, lie with my reputation:
I am poor besides.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Ye are all wealth and goodness;
And none but such as are the scum of men,
The ulcers of an honest state; spite-weavers,
That live on poison only, like swollen spiders,
dare once profane such excellence, such sweetness.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This man speaks loud indeed.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Name but the men, lady;
Let me but know these poor, and base depravers;
Lay but to my revenge their persons open,
And you shall see how suddenly, how fully
For your most beauteous sake, how direfully
I'll handle their despites. Is this thing one?
Be what he will.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Dare your malicious tongue, sir?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I know you not; nor what ye mean.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Good my lord.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: If he, or any he.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I beseech your honour.
This gentleman's a stranger to my knowledge,
And no doubt, sir, a worthy man.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Your mercy;
But had ye been attaint of your honour;
A blaster of those beauties reign within ye;
But we shall find a fitter time: dear lady,
As soon as I have freed ye from your guardian,
And done some honoured offices unto ye,
I'll take ye with those faults the world flings on ye;
And dearer than the whole world I'll esteem ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This is a thundering lord; I am glad I scaped him:
How lovingly the wench disclaimed my villainy?
I am vexed now heartily that he shall have her;
Not that I care to marry, or to lose her;
But that this bilbo-lord shall reap that maidenhead
That was my due; that he shall rig and top her;
I'd give a thousand crowns now, he might miss her.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Nay, if I bear your blows, and keep your council,
You have good luck, sir; I'll teach ye to strike lighter.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come hither, honest fellow; canst thou tell me
Where this great lord lies? This Savoy lord? Thou metst him;
He now went by thee certain.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes, he did, sir;
I know him; and I know you are fooled.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come hither.
Here's all this, give me truth.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Not for your money;
(And yet that may do much) but I have been beaten:
And by the worshipful contrivers beaten; and I'll tell ye;
This is no lord, no Savoy lord.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Go forward.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: This is a trick, and put upon ye grossly
By one Lugier; the lord is monsieur De-gard, sir;
An honest gentleman, and a neighbour here;
Their ends you understand better than I, sure.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Now I know him.
Know him now plain.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I have discharged my colours; so God by ye, sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What a purblind puppy was I; now I remember him.
All the whole cast on's face, though 'twere umbered,
And masked with patches: what a dunder-whelp
To let him domineer thus: how he strutted,
And what a load of lord he clapped upon him?
Would I had him here again, I would so bounce him,
I would so thank his lordship for his lewd plot:
Do they think to carry it away, with a great band made of bird pots.
And a pair of pin-buttocked breeches? Ha! 'tis he again
He comes, he comes, he comes; have at him. Enter De-gard, Oriana, etc.

sp.speaker: Sings.
sp.l: My Savoy lord, why dost thou frown on me?
And will that favour never sweeter be?
Wilt thou I say, for ever play the fool?
De-gard, be wise, and Savoy go to school.
My lord De-gard, I thank ye for your antic,
My lady bright, that will be sometime frantic;
You worthy train, that wait upon this pair,
'Send you more wit, and they a bouncing baire;
And so I take my humble leave of your honours. Exit.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: We are discovered, there's no remedy;
Lelia, Biancha's man upon my life,
In stubbornness, because Lugier corrected him.
(A shameless slaves-plague on him for a rascal.)

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I was in a perfect hope; the bane on't is now;
He will make mirth on mirth, to persecute us.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: We must be patient; I am vexed to the proof too.
I'll try once more; then if I fail: here's one speaks.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Let me be lost, and scorned first.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Well, we'll consider.
Away, and let me shift; I shall be hooted else. Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quartus. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Leug.
sp.l: Faint not; but do as I direct ye, trust me;
Believe me too, for what I have told ye, (Lady)
As true as you are Lelia, is authentic;
I know it; I have found it; 'tis a poor courage
Flies off for one repulse; these travellers
Shall find before we have done, a homespun wit,
A plain French understanding may cope with 'em;
They have had the better yet, thank your sweet squire, here;
And let 'em brag: you would be revenged?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Yes surely.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: And married too?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I think so.

sp.speaker: Leug.
sp.l: Then be counselled;
You know how to proceed: I have other irons
Heating as well as yours: and I will strike
Three blows with one stone home, be ruled, and happy;
And so I leave ye. Now is the time.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I am ready.
If he do come to do me.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Will ye stand here,
And let the people think, ye are God knows what, mistress;
Let boys, and prentices presume upon ye.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Prithee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Stand at his door, that hates ye?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Prithee leave prating.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Pray ye go to th' tavern. I'll give ye a pint of wine there;
If any of the madcap gentlemen should come by
That take up women upon special warrant,
You were in a wise case now.

div.stage: Enter, Mirabell, Pinac, Mariana, priest, attendants.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Give me the garland,
And wait you here.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: She is here to seek thee, sirrah.
I told thee what would follow; she is mad, for thee;
Show, and advance. So early stirring lady,
It shows a busy mind; a fancy troubled:
A willow garland too. Is't possible,
'Tis pity so much beauty should lie musty,
But 'tis not to be helped now.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: The more's my misery
Good fortune to ye (Lady) you deserve it:
To me: too late repentance; I have sought it:
I do not envy, though I grieve a little,
You are mistress of that happiness, those joys
That might have been, had I been wise: but fortune.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: She understands ye not, pray ye do not trouble her;
And do not cross me like a hare thus, 'tis as ominous.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I come not to upbraid, your levity.
Though ye made show of love, and though I liked ye
To claim an interest; we are yet both strangers,
But what we might have been, had you persevered, sir,
To be an eyesore to your loving lady;
This garland shows, I give myself forsaken;
(Yet she must pardon me, 'tis most unwillingly:)
And all the power and interest I had in ye?
As I persuade myself, somewhat ye loved me;
Thus patiently I render up, I offer
To her that must enjoy ye: and so bless ye;
Only, I heartily desire this courtesy,
And would not be denied: to wait upon ye
This day, to see ye tide, then no more trouble ye.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: It need not, lady.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Good, sir, grant me so much.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: 'Tis private, and we make no invitation.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: My presence, sir, shall not proclaim it public.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: May be 'tis not in town.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I have a coach, sir.
And a most ready will to do you service.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Strike now or never; make it sure: I tell thee,
She will hang herself; if she have thee not.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Pray ye, sir,
Entertain my noble mistress: only a word or two
With this importunate woman, and I'll relieve ye.
Now ye see what your flings are, and your fancies,
Your states, and your wild stubbornness, now ye find
What 'tis to gird and kick at men's fair services,
To raise your pride to such a pitch, and glory
That goodness shows like gnats, scorned under ye,
'Tis ugly, naught, a self will in a woman,
Chained to an overweening thought, is pestilent,
Murders fair fortune first; then fair opinion?
There stands a pattern, a true patient pattern,
Humble, and sweet.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I can but grieve my ignorance.
Repentance some say too, is the best sacrifice;
For sure, sir, if my chance had been so happy,
(As I confess I was mine own destroyer)
As to have arrived at you; I will not prophesy,
But certain, as I think, I should have pleased ye;
Have made ye as much wonder at my courtesy,
My love, and duty, as I have disheartened ye,
Some hours we have of youth, and some of folly;
And being freeborn maids, we take a liberty,
And to maintain that, sometimes we strain highly.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Now ye talk reason.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: But being yoked, and governed,
Married, and those light vanities purged from us;
How fair we grow, how gentle, and how tender
We twine about those loves that shoot-up with us?
A sullen woman fear, that talks not to ye;
She has a sad and darkened soul, loves dully:
A merry and a free wench, give her liberty;
Believe her in the lightest form she appears to ye;
Believe her excellent, though she despise ye;
Let but these fits and flashes pass, she will show to ye;
As jewels rubbed from dust, or gold new burnished:
Such had I been, had you believed.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Is't possible.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: And to your happiness, I dare assure ye
If true love be accounted so; your pleasure,
Your will, and your command had tied my motions:
But that hopes gone; I know you are young, and giddy,
And till you have a wife can govern with ye,
You sail upon this world-sea, light and empty;
Your bark in danger daily; 'tis not the name neither
Of wife can steer ye; but the noble nature,
the diligence, the care, the love, the patience,
She makes the pilot, and preserves the husband,
That knows, and reckons every rib, he is built on;
But this I tell ye, to my shame.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I admire ye,
And now am sorry, that I aim beyond ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: So, so, so: fair and softly. She is thine own (Boy)
She comes now, without lure.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: But that it must needs
Be reckoned to me as a wantonness,
Or worse, a madness, to forsake a blessing,
A blessing of that hope.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I dare not urge ye;
And yet dear, sir.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: 'Tis most certain, I had rather,
If 'twere in mine own choice, for you are my countrywoman,
A neighbour here born by me, she a stranger;
And who knows how her friends?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Do as you please, sir,
If ye be fast: not all the world: I love ye,
'Tis most true: and clear, I would persuade ye;
And I shall love ye still.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Go, get before me:
So much ye have won upon me: do it presently:
Here's a priest ready: I'll have you.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Not now, sir,
No, you shall pardon me: advance your lady,
I dare not hinder your most high preferment,
'Tis honour enough for me, I have unmasked ye.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: How's that.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I have caught ye, sir; alas, I am no state's woman,
Nor no great traveller, yet I have found ye,
I have found your lady too: your beauteous lady;
I have found her birth, and breeding too: her discipline:
Who brought her over, and who kept your lady:
And when he laid her by, what virtuous nunnery
Received her in: I have found all these: are ye blank now,
Methinks such travelled wisdoms should not fool thus:
Such excellent indiscretions.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How could she know this?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: 'Tis true she is English born: but most part French now,
And so I hope you will find her, to your comfort,
Alas, I am ignorant of what, she cost ye:
The price of these hired clothes I do not know gentlemen;
Those jewels are the brokers, how ye stand bound for 'em.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Will you make this good?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and to her face, sir,
That she is an English whore, a kind of fling dust
One of your London light o'loves: a right one,
Came over in thin pumps; and half a petticoat,
One faith, and one smock, with a broken haberdasher;
I know all this, without a conjurer:
Her name is Jumping-joan, an ancient sin-weaver;
she was first a lady's chambermaid, there slipped
And broke her leg above the knee: departed
And set up shop herself. Stood the fierce conflicts
Of many a furious term; there lost her colours,
And last shipped over hither.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: We are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Do you come to fright me with this mystery?
To stir me with a stink none can endure, sir?
I pray ye proceed, the wedding will become ye,
Who gives the lady? you? an excellent father:
A careful man, and one that knows a beauty,
'Send ye fair shipping, sir, and so I'll leave ye;
Be wise and manly, than I may chance to love ye. â€” exit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: As I live I am ashamed, this wench has reached me,
Monstrous ashamed, but there's no remedy,
This skewed-eyed carrion.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: This I suspected ever,
Come, come, uncase, we have no more use of ye;
Your clothes, must back again.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Sir, ye shall pardon me:
'Tis not our English use to be degraded:
I you will visit me and take your venture,
You shall have pleasure for your properties;
And so sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Let her go, and the devil go with her:
We have never better luck with these preludiums:
Come, be not daunted: think she is but a woman,
And let her have the devil's wit, we'll reach her. â€” exit.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Ye have now redeemed my good opinion (Tutor)
And ye stand fair again.

sp.speaker: Lug
sp.l: I can but labour,
And sweat in your affairs: I am sure Bellure:
Will be here instantly, and use his anger
His wonted harshness.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I hope he will not beat me.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: No sure; he has more manners: be you ready.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I am: and am resolved to fit him,
With patience to outdo all he can offer;
But how does Oriana?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Worse, and worse still:
There is a sad house for her: she is now
Poor lady, utterly distracted.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Pity:
Infinite pity: 'tis a handsome lady,
That Mirabel's a beast, worse than a monster.
If this affliction work not.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Are ye ready?
Bellure is coming on, here, hard behind me,
I have no leisure to relate my fortune.
Only I wish you may come off as handsomely,
Upon the sign you know what. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Well, well, leave me. Enter Bellure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Ye are welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis well ye have manners:
That curtsy again, and hold your countenance staidly;
That looks too light; take heed: so, sit ye down now,
And to confirm me that your gall is gone,
Your bitterness dispersed, for so I'll have it;
Look on me steadfastly; and whatsoe'er I say to ye,
Move not, nor alter in your face, ye are gone then;
For if you do express the least distaste,
Or show an angry wrinkle; mark me, woman,
We are now alone, I will so conjure thee:
The third part of my execution
Cannot be spoke.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I am at your dispose, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now rise, and woo me a little, let me hear that faculty;
But touch me not; nor do not lie, I charge ye.
Begin now.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: If so mean and poor a beauty
May ever hope the grace.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ye cog, ye flatter
Like a lewd thing, ye lie: may hope that grace?
Why, what grace canst thou hope for? Answer not,
For if thou dost, and liest again, I'll swinge thee;
Do not I know thee, for a pestilent woman?
A proud at both ends? Be not angry;
Nor stir not of your life?

sp.speaker: Ros
sp.l: I am counselled, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Art thou not now, (Confess, for I'll have the truth out)
As much unworthy of a man of merit,
Or any of ye all? Nay of mere man?
Though he were crooked, cold, all wants upon him;
Nay of any dishonest thing, that bears that figure;
As devils are of mercy?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: We are unworthy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stick to that truth, and it may chance to save thee;
And is it not our bounty that we take ye?
That we are troubled, vexed, or tortured with ye?
Our mere, and special bounty?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Our pity,
That for your wickedness we swinge ye soundly;
Your stubbornness and stout hearts, we belabour ye?
Answer, to that?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I do confess your pity.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And dost not thou deserve in thine own person?
(Thou impudent, thou pert; do not change countenance?)

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I dare not, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For if ye do.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I am settled.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Thou wagtail, peacock, puppy; look on me:
I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: It seems no less, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And darest thou in thy surquedry?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I beseech ye.
It was my weakness, sir; I did not view ye;
I took not notice of your noble parts;
Nor called your person, nor your proper fashion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This is some amends yet.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I shall mend, sir, daily.
And study to deserve.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Come a little nearer:
Canst thou repent thy villainy?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Most seriously.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And be ashamed?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I am ashamed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Cry.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: It will be hard to do, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Cry now instantly;
Cry monstrously, that all the town may hear thee;
Cry seriously; as if thou hadst lost thy monkey;
And as I like thy tears. Enter Lilia and four women laughing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How? How? do ye jeer me?
Have ye broke your bounds again dame?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes, and laugh at ye;
And laugh most heartily.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What are these, whirlwinds?
Is hell broke loose, and all the furies fluttered?
Am I greased once again?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes indeed are ye;
And once again ye shall be, if ye quarrel:
Do you come to vent your fury on a virgin?
Is this your manhood, sir?

sp.speaker: 1. Wo.
sp.l: Let him do his best:
Let's see the utmost of his indignation:
I long to see him angry: come, proceed, sir.
Hang him, he dares not stir; a man of timber.

sp.speaker: 2. Woman
sp.l: Come hither to fright maids, with thy bul-faces?
To threaten gentlewomen? Thou a man? A maypole.
A great dry pudding.

sp.speaker: 3. Woman
sp.l: Come, come, do your worst, sir;
Be angry if thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The lord deliver me.

sp.speaker: 4. Woman
sp.l: Do but look scurvily upon this lady,
Or give us one foul word. We are all mistaken;
This is some mighty dairy-maid in man's clothes.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: I am of that mind too.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What will they do to me?

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: And hired to come and abuse us; a man has manners;
A gentleman, civility, and breeding:
some tinker's trull with a beard glued on.

sp.speaker: 1. Wo.
sp.l: Let's search him;
And as we find him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Let me but depart from ye,
Sweet Christian women.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Hear the thing speak, neighbours.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis but a small request: if ere I trouble ye,
If ere I talk again of beating women,
Or beating any thing that can but turn to me;
Of ever thinking of a handsome lady
But virtuously and well: of ever speaking
But to her honour: this I'll promise ye,
I will take rhubarb; and purge choler mainly,
Abundantly I'll purge.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I'll send ye broths, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I will be laughed at, and endure it patiently,
I will do any thing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I'll be your bail then:
When ye come next to woo, pray ye come not boisterously
And furnished like a bearward.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No in truth, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I scented ye long since.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I was to blame, sure;
I will appear a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: 'Tis the best for ye,
For a true noble gentleman's a brave thing;
Upon that hope we quit ye: you fear seriously?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes truly do I; I confess I fear ye,
And honour ye, and any thing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Farewell then.

sp.speaker: Woman
sp.l: And when ye come to woo next bring more mercy. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A dairy-maid? A tinker's trull: heaven bless me:
Sure if I had provoked 'em, they had quartered me. Enter two gentlemen.
I am a most ridiculous ass, now I perceive it:
A coward, and a knave too.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: 'Tis the mad gentleman.
Let's set our faces right.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No, no, laugh at me;
And laugh aloud.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: We are better mannered, sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I do deserve it; call me patch, and puppy,
And beat me if you please.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.l: No indeed: we know ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Death, do as I would have ye.

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: Ye are an ass then;
A coxcomb, and a calf.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am a great calf:
Kick me a little now: why, when? Sufficient:
Now laugh aloud, and scorn me; so good bye;
And ever when ye meet me laugh.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: We will, sir.

div.head: Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Nantolet, La-castre, De-gard, Lugier, Mirabell.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Your patience, gentlemen; why do ye bait me?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Is't not a shame you are so stubborn-hearted,
So stony and so dull to such a lady,
Of her perfections, and her misery?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Does she not love ye? does not her distraction
For your sake only, her most pitied lunacy
Of all but you, show ye? does it not compel ye?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Soft and fair, gentlemen, pray ye proceed temperately.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: If ye have any feeling, any sense in ye,
The least touch of a noble heart.

sp.speaker: Le-cast.
sp.l: Let him alone;
It is his glory that he can kill beauty,
Ye bear my stamp, but not my tenderness;
Your wild unsavoury courses set that in ye!
For shame be sorry, though ye cannot cure her,
Show something of a man, of a fair nature.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ye make me mad.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Let me pronounce this to ye,
You take a strange felicity in slighting
And wronging women; which my poor sister feels now,
Heaven's hand be gentle on her: mark me, sir,
That very hour she dies; there's small hope otherwise,
That minute you and I must grapple for it;
Either your life or mine.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Be not so hot, sir,
I am not to be wrought on by these policies;
In truth I am not; nor do I fear the tricks,
Or the high sounding threats of a savoyen:
I glory not in cruelty; ye wrong me;
Nor grow up watered with the tears of women;
This let me tell ye, howsoe'er I show to ye
Wild, as you please to call it; or self-willed;
When I see cause, I can both do, and suffer,Enter Rosaluce and Lelia.
Freely, and feelingly, as a true gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O pity, pity; thousand thousand pities!

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Alas, poor soul! she will die; she is grown senseless;
She will not know, nor speak now.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Die for love,
And love of such a youth? I would die for a dog, first.
He that kills me, I'll give him leave to eat me;
I'll know men better ere I sigh for any of 'em.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Ye have done a worthy act, sir; a most famous;
Ye have killed a maid the wrong way; ye are a conqueror.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: A conqueror? A cobbler; hang him Sowter;
Go hid thyself for shame; go lose thy memory;
Live not amongst men; thou art a beast, a monster;
A blatant beast.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: If ye have yet any honesty,
or ever heard of any; take my counsel;
Off with your garters; and seek out a bough,
A handsome bough; (For I would have ye hang like a gentleman;)
And write some doleful matter to the world,
A warning to hard-hearted men.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Out kitlings:
What catterwalling's here? what gibbing?
Do you think my heart is softened with a black santis;
Show me some reason. Enter Oriana on a bed.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Here then, here is a reason.

sp.speaker: Nant.
sp.l: Now, if ye be a man, let this sight shake ye.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Alas poor gentlewoman! do ye know me lady?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: How she looks up and stares.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I know ye very well:
You are my godfather; and that's the monsieur.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: And who am I?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: You are Amadis de Gaul, sir.
O, o, my heart! were you never in love, sweet lady?
And do you never dream of flowers and gardens;
I dream of walking fires: take heed, it comes now,
Who's that? pray stand away, I have seen that face sure;
How light my head is.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Take some rest.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I cannot.
For I must be up tomorrow, to go to church:
And I must dress me, put my new gown on,
And be as fine to meet my love: heigh ho!
Will not you tell me where my love lies buried?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: He is not dead: beshrew my heart she stirs me.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: He is dead to me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is't possible my nature
Should be so damnable, to let her suffer;
Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: How soft you feel; how gentle?
I'll tell ye your fortune, friend.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How she stares on me?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: You have a flattering face; but 'tis a fine one;
I warrant you may have a hundred sweethearts:
Will ye pray for me? I shall die tomorrow;
And will ye ring the bells?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I am most unworthy;
I do confess unhappy; do you know me?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I would I did.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: O fair tears; how ye take me.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Do you weep too? you have not lost your lover?
You mock me: I'll go home and pray.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pray ye pardon me:
Or if it please ye to consider justly,
Scorn me; for I deserve it: scorn, and shame me:
Sweet Oriana.

sp.speaker: Lei.
sp.l: Let her alone; she trembles.
Her fits will grow more strong, if ye provoke her;

sp.speaker: Ca-last
sp.l: Certain she knows ye not, yet loves to see ye
How she smiles now:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Where are ye? o, why do not ye laugh: come laugh at me;
Why a devil, art thou sad, and such a subject,
Such a ridiculous subject, as I am
Before thy face?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Prithee put off this lightness,
This is no time for mirth, nor place: I have used too much on't:
I have undone myself and a sweet lady,
By being too indulgent to my foolery
Which truly I repent: look here.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What ails she.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Alas she is mad.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mad.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, too sure for me too.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dost thou wonder at that? by this good light, they are all so;
They are cozening mad, they are brawling mad, they are proud mad.
They are all, all mad: I came from a world of mad women,
Mad as march hairs: get 'em in chains, then deal with 'em.
There's one that's mad: she seems well, but she is dog mad:
Is she dead, dost think?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Dead? heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Bael
sp.l: Heaven further it.
For till they be key-cold dead, there's no trusting of 'em
Whate'er they seem, or howsoe'er they carry it,
Till they be chap-fallen, and their tongues at peace,
Nailed in their coffins sure, I'll never believe 'em,
Shall I talk with her.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, dear friend, be quiet;
And be at peace a while.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll walk aside ,
And come again anon: but take heed to her
You say she is a woman?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Take great heed:
For if she do not cozen thee, then hang me:
Let her be mad, or what she will, she'll cheat theeâ€” exit

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Away wild fool: how vild this shows in him now?
Now take my faith, before ye all I speak it,
And with it, my repentant love.

sp.speaker: La-cast.
sp.l: This seems well.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Were but this lady leer again, whose sorrows
My very heart melts for; were she but perfect
(For thus to marry her, would be two miseries,)
Before the rishest, and the noblest beauty,
France, or the world could show me; I would take her
As she is now, my tears, and prayers shall wed her.

sp.speaker: De-ga.
sp.l: This makes some small amends.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: She beckons to ye.
To us too, to go off.

sp.speaker: Nant.
sp.l: Let's draw aside all.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: O my best friend: I would feign.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What? she speaks well,
And with another voice.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: But I am fearful,
And shame a little, stops my tongue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Tell ye, I am well, I am perfect well. Pray ye mock not;
And that I did this to provoke your nature,
Out of my infinite, and restless love,
To win your pity: pardon me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Go forward;
Who set ye on?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: None, as I live, no creature.
Not any knew, or ever dreamt, what I meant:
Will ye be mine?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I pity ye;
But when I marry ye, ye must be wiser;
Nothing but tricks? devices?

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Will ye shame me?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, marry will I: come near, come near, a miracle,
The woman's well: she was only mad for marriage,
Stark mad to be stoned to death; give her good council,
Will this world never mend? are ye caught, damsel?

div.stage: Enter Bellure, la. Castre, Lugier, Nantolet, De-gard, Rosaluce, Bianth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How goes it now?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Thou art a kind of prophet,
The woman's well again; and would have gulled me,
Well, excellent well: and not a taint upon her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Did not I tell ye? Let 'em be what can be;
Saints, devils, any thing, they will abuse us;
Thou wert an ass to believe her so long: a coxcomb;
Give 'em a minute, they'll abuse whole millions.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And am not I a rare physician, gentlemen?
That can cure desperate mad minds?

sp.speaker: De-ga.
sp.l: Be not insolent.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways: from this hour, I disclaim thee,
Unless thou hast a trick above this: then I'll love thee.
Ye owe me for your cure; pray have a care of her,
For fear she fall into relapse; come Bellure
We'll set up bills, to cure diseased virgins.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Shall we be merry?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But I'll no more projects;
If we could make 'em mad, it were some mastery. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: I am glad she is well again.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: So am I, certain
Be not ashamed.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: I shall never see a man more.

sp.speaker: De-g
sp.l: Come ye are a fool: had ye but told me this trick,
He should not have gloried thus.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: He shall not long neither.

sp.speaker: La-cast
sp.l: Be ruled, and be at peace: ye have my consent,
And what power I can work with.

sp.speaker: Nant.
sp.l: Come, leave blushing;
We are your friends; an honest way compelled ye;
Heaven will not see so true a love unrecompensed;
Come in, and slight him too.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: The next shall hit him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: 'Twill be discovered.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: That's the worst can happen:
If there be any way, to reach, and work upon him;
Upon his nature suddenly, and catch him: that he loves,
Though he dissemble it, and would show contrary,
And will at length relent: I'll lay my fortune,
Nay more, my life.

sp.speaker: De G.
sp.l: Is she won?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Yes, and ready,
And my designments set.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: They are now for travel,
All for that game again: they have forgotten wooing.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Let 'em; we'll travel with 'em.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Where's his father?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Within; he knows my mind too, and allows it;
Pities your sister's fortune most sincerely;
And has appointed, for our more assistance,
Some of his secret friends.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: 'Speed the plough.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Well said;
And be you serious too.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: I shall be diligent.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Let's break the ice for one, the rest will drink too
(Believe me, sir) of the same cup; my young gentlewomen
Wait but who sets the game a foot; though they seem 'Stubborn,
Reserved, and proud now, yet I know their hearts,
Their pulses, how they beat, and for what cause, sir;
And how they long to venture their abilities
In a true quarrel; husbands they must, and will have,
Or nunneries, and thin collations
To cool their bloods; let's all about our business,
And if this fail, let nature work.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Ye have armed me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: La Cast.
sp.l: Will ye be wilful then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pray, sir, your pardon,
For I must travel: lie lazy here;
Bound to a wife; chained to her subtleties,
Her humours, and her wills, which are mere fetters;
To have her today pleased, tomorrow peevish,
The third day mad, the fourth rebellious;
You see, before they are married, what moriscoes,
what masques, and mummeries they put upon us,
To be tied here, and suffer their lavaltoes?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: 'Tis your own seeking.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, to get my freedom;
Were they as I could wish 'em.

sp.speaker: La-cast
sp.l: Fool's, and meacocks,
To endure what you think fit to put upon 'em:
Come, change your mind.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Not before I have changed air (Father)
When I know women worthy of my company,
I will return again and wait upon 'em;
Till then (Dear sir) I'll amble all the world over,
And run all hazards, misery, and poverty,Enter Pinac and Bellure.
So I escape the dangerous bay of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Are ye resolved?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes certain; I will out again.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: We are for ye, sir; we are your servants once more;
Once more we'll seek our fortune in strange countries;
Ours is too scornful for us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Is there ne'er a land
That ye have read, or head of, (For I care not how far it be,
Nor under what pestiferous star it lies)
A happy kingdom, where there are no women?
Nor have been ever? Nor no mention
Of any such lewd things, with lewder qualities?
For thither would I travel; where 'tis felony
To confess he had a mother: a mistress, treason?

sp.speaker: La-cast
sp.l: Are you for travel too?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: For any thing;
For living in the moon, and stopping hedges,
E'er I stay here to be abused, and baffled.

sp.speaker: Nant.
sp.l: Why did ye not break your minds to me? They are my daughters;
And sure I think I should have that command over 'em?
To see 'em well bestowed: I know ye are gentlemen,
Men of fair parts and states; I know your parents;
And had ye told me of your fair affections:
Make but one trial more; and let me second ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No I'll make hobnails first, and mend old kettles:
Can ye lend me an armour of high proof, to appear in,
And two or three field pieces to defend me?
The King's guard are mere pigmeys.

sp.speaker: Nant.
sp.l: They will not eat ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, and you too, and twenty fatter monsieurs,
If their high stomachs hold: they came with chopping-knives,
To cut me into rands, and surloyns, and so powder me.
Come, shall we go?

sp.speaker: Nant.
sp.l: You cannot be so discourteous
(If ye intend to go) as not to visit 'em,
And take your leaves.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: That we dare do, and civilly,
And thank 'em too.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Yes, sir, we know that honesty.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll come i'th rear, forty foot off, I'll assure ye,
With a good gun in my hand; I'll no more Amazous,
I mean, no more of their frights; I'll make my three legs,
Kiss my hand twice; and if I smell no danger;
If the interview be clear, may be I'll speak to her;
I'll wear a privy coat too; and behind me,
To make those parts secure, a bandog.

sp.speaker: La-cast
sp.l: You are a merry gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A wary gentleman; I do assure ye,
I have been warned, and must be armed.

sp.speaker: La-cast
sp.l: Well, son,
These are your hasty thoughts, when I see you are bent to it,
Then I'll believe, and join with ye; so we'll leave ye:
There's a trick will make ye stay.

sp.speaker: Nant.
sp.l: I hope so. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: We have won immortal fame now, if we leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: You have, but we have lost.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pinac, thou art cozened;
I know they love ye; and to gain ye handsomely,
Not to be thought to yield, they would give millions;
Their father's willingness, that must needs show ye.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: If I thought so.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ye shall be hanged, ye recreant,
Would ye turn renegado no?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No let's away, boys,
Out of the air, and tumult of their villainies;
Though I were married to that grasshopper,
And had her fast by th' legs I should think she would cozen me.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Monsieur Mirabel, I take it? Enter a young factor.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You're ith' right, sir.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: I am come to seek ye, sir; I have been at your fathers,
And understanding you were here.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ye are welcome:
May I crave your name?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Fossae, sir, and your servant;
That you may know me better; I am factor
To your old merchant, Leverdure.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How does he?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Well, sir, I hope: he is now at Orleans,
About some business.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You are once more welcome.
Your master's a right honest man; and one
I am much beholding too, and must very shortly
Trouble his love again.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: You may be bold, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Your business if you please now?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: This it is, sir.
I know ye well remember in your travel
A Genoa merchant.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I remember many.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: But this man, sir, particularly; your own benefit
Must needs imprint him in ye: one Alberto;
a gentleman you saved from being murdered
A little from Bologna,
I was then myself in Italy, and supplied ye,
Though happily, you have forgotten me now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, I remember ye,
And that Alberto too: a noble gentleman:
More to remember, were to thank myself, sir.
What of that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: He is dead:

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I am sorry.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: But on his death bed, leaving to his sister.
All that he had beside some certain jewels,
Which with a ceremony, he bequeathed to you,
In grateful memory: he commanded strictly
His sister, as she loved him and his peace,
To see those jewels safe, and true delivered;
And with them, his last love. She, as tender
To observe this will, not trusting friend, nor servant,
With such a weight, is come herself to Paris
And at my master's house.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You tell me a wonder.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: I tell ye a truth, sir: she is young, and handsome,
And well attended: of much state, and riches;
So loving, and obedient to her brother;
That on my conscience, if he had given her also,
She would most willingly have made her tender.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: May not I see her?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: She desires it heartily.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And presently?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: She is now about some business,
Passing accounts of some few debts here owing,
And buying jewels of a merchant,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Is she wealthy.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: I would ye had her, sir, at all adventure.
Her brother had, a main state.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And fair too?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: The prime of all those parts of Italy,
For beauty, and for courtesy.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I must needs see her.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: 'Tis all her business, sir. Ye may now see her,
But tomorrow will be fitter for your visitation;
For she is not yet prepared.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Only, her sight, sir.
And when you shall think fit for further visit.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Sir, ye may see her; and I'll wait your coming.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: And I'll be with ye instantly: I know the house,
Mean time, my love, and thanks, sir.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Your poor servantâ€” exit.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Thou hast the strangest luck: what was that Alberto?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: An honest noble merchant, 'twas my chance
To rescue from some rogues had almost slain him;
And he in kindness to remember this.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now we shall have you:
For all your protestations, and your forwardness,
Find out strange fortunes in this lady's eyes,
And new entirements to put off your journey;
And who shall have honour then?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, no, never fear it:
I must needs see her, to receive my legacy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If it be tide up in her smock, heaven help thee:
May not we see too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, afore we go:
I must be known myself e'er I be able
To make thou welcome: wouldst thou see more women?
I thought you had been out of love with all:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I may be,
I find that with the least encouragement:
Yet I desire to see whether all countries
Are naturally possessed with the same spirits;
For if they be, I'll take a monastery,
And never travel; for I had rather be a friar,
And live mewed up, then be a fool, and flouted:

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well, well, I'll meet ye anon; then tell you more, boys;
Howe'er , stand prepared, pressed for our journey;
For certain, we shall go, I think, when I have seen her.
And viewed her well.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Go, go, and we'll wait for ye;
Your fortune directs ours.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You shall find us ith' tavern,
Lamenting in sack and sugar for our losses;
If she be right Italian, and want servants,
You may prefer the properest man.
How I could worry a woman now?

sp.speaker: Pi:
sp.l: Come, come, leave prating;
Ye may have enough to do, without this boastingExeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Lugier, De-gard, Rosalu. and Lillia.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: This is the last adventure.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: And the happiest,
As we hope too.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: We should be glad to find it.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Who shall conduct us thither?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Your man is ready.
For I must not be seen; no, nor this gentleman;
That may beget suspicion: all the rest
Are people of no doubt; I would have ye, ladies,
Keep your old liberties, and as we instruct ye:
Come, look not pale; you shall not lose your wishes;
Nor beg 'em neither: but be yourselves, and happy.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I tell ye true, I cannot hold off longer,
Nor give no more hard language.

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: You shall not need.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I love the gentleman, and must now show it;
Shall I beat a proper man out of heart?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: There's none advises ye.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: I'faith I repent me too.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Repent, and spoil all.
Tell what ye know, ye had best.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: I'll tell what I think;
For if he ask me now, if I can love him,
I'll tell him yes, I can: the man's a kind man;
and out of his true honesty affect me;
Although he played the fool, which I requited;
Must I still hold him at the stave's end?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: You are two strange woman.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: We may be, if we fool still.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Dare ye believe me?
Follow but this advice I have set you in now,
And if ye lose: would ye yield now so basely?
Give up without your honours saved?

sp.speaker: De G.
sp.l: Fie, ladies.
Preserve your freedom still.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Well, well, for this time.

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: And carry that full state.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: That's as the wind stands:
If it begin to chop about, and scant u;
Hang me, but I know what I'll do: come direct us,
I make no doubt, we shall do handsomely:

sp.speaker: De-g.
sp.l: Some part o'th' way, we'll wait upon ye, ladies;
The rest your man supplies:

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: Do well, I'll honour ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaen. 4.
div.stage: Enter factor and Mirabel, Oriana and two merchants.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Look ye, sir, there she is, you see how busy;
Methinks you are infinitely bound to her, for her journey.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How gloriously she shows? She is a tall woman.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Of a fair size, sir. My master not being at home,
I have been so out of my wits, to get her company:
I mean, sir, of her own fair sex, and fashion.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Afar off, she is most fair too.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Near, most excellent.
At length, I have entreated two fair ladies,
And happily you know 'em: the young daughters
Of monsieur Nantolet.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I know 'em well, sir.
What are those? Jewels?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: They make a rich show?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: There is a matter of ten thousand pounds too
Was owing here: you see those merchants with her;
They have brought it in now.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How handsomely her shape shows?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Those are still neat: your Italians are most curious
Now she looks this way.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: She has a goodly presence.
How full of courtesy? Well, sir, I'll leave ye.
And if I may be bold to bring a friend or two;
Good noble gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: No doubt, ye may, sir.
For you have most command.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I have seen a wonder. Exit.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Taken to the utmost.
A wonder dwells about him.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: He did not guess at me?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: No, be secure; ye show another woman.
He is gone to fetch his friends.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Where are the gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Here, here, now they are come,Enter Rosaluce, Lillia, servant.
Sit still, and let them see ye.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Pray ye, where's my friend, sir?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: She is within, ladies, but here's another gentlewoman;
A stranger to this town: so please you visit her,
'Twill be well taken.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: There, above; ladies.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Bless me: what thing is this? two pinnacles,
Upon her pate! Is't not a glode to catch woodcocks?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Peace, ye rude, knave.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: What a bouncing bum she has too?
There's sail enough for a carack.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What is this lady?
For as I live, she's a goodly woman.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Guess, guess.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: I have not seen a nobler presence.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: 'Tis a lusty wench: now could I spend my fortypence,
With all my heart, to have but one fling at her;
To give her but a washing blow.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Ye rascal.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I that's all a man has, for's goodwill: 'twil be long enough,
Before ye cry come Anthony, and kiss me.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: I'll have ye whipped.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Has my friend seen this lady?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Yes, yes, and is well known to her.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I much admire her presence.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: So do I too:
For I protest, she is the handsomest,
The rarest, and the newest to mine eye
That ever, I saw yet.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I long to know her;
My friend shall do that kindness.

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: So she shall ladies.
Come, pray ye come up.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: O, me,

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Hang me if I knew her:
Were I a man myself, I should now love ye;
Nay, I should dote.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I dare not, trust mine eyes;
For as I live ye are the strangest altered
I must come up to know the truth.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: So must I, lady;
For I am a kind of unbeliever too.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Get ye gone, sirrah;
And what ye have seen, be secret in: you are paid else;
No more of your long tongue.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Will ye go in ladies,
And talk with her. These venturers will come straight:
Away with this fellow.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: There, sirrah, go, disport ye.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: I would the trunk-hosed woman, would go with me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Is she so glorious handsome?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You would wonder:
Our women look like Gipsies, like gills to her:
Their clothes and fashions beggarly, and bankrupt:
Base, old, and scurvy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How looks her face?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Most heavenly:
And the becoming-motion of her body
So sets her off.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why then we shall stay.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Pardon me:
That's more than I know: if she be that woman,
She appears to be.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I shall then tell ye more.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Did ye speak to her?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No, no, I only saw her: she was busy
Now I go for that end: and mark her (Gentlemen)
If she appear, not to ye, one of the sweetest,
The handsomest: the fairest, in behaviour,
We shall meet the two wenches there too, they come to visit her,
To wonder, as we do.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Then we shall meet 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I had rather meet two bears.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: There you may take your leaves, dispatch that business,
And as ye find their humours.

sp.speaker: Pi
sp.l: Is your love there too?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: No certain, she has no great heart to set out again.
This is the house, I'll usher ye?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll bless me,
And take a good heart if I can:

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Come, noblyExeunt.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: They are come in: sit you two off, as strangers,
There lady: where's the boy? be ready, sirrah
And clear your pipes, the music now: they enter. Music. then enter Mirabell, Pinac and Bellure.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: What a state she keeps? how far off they sit, from her?
How rich she is, I marry, this shows bravely.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She is a lusty wench: and may allure a good man,
But if she have a tongue, I'll not give two pence for her:
There fits my fury: how I shake to see her.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Madam this is the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mir,
sp.l: How sweet she kisses?
She has a spring dwells on her lips: a paradise
This is the legacy.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: From the honoured dead I bring
Thus his love and last offering

sp.speaker: Ori.
sp.l: Most noble, sir.
This from my now dead brother, as his love,
And grateful memory of your great benefit:
From me my thanks, my wishes, and my service,
Till I am more acquainted I am silent.
Only I dare say this, you are truly noble.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What should I think?

sp.speaker: Pi
sp.l: Think ye have a handsome fortune,
Would I had such another.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Ye are well met gentlemen,
We hear ye are for travel?

sp.speaker: Pi
sp.l: Ye hear true, lady,
And come to take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: We'll along with ye,
We see you are grown so witty by your journey,
We cannot choose but step out too: this lady,
we mean to wait upon as far as Italy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll travel into Wales, amongst the mountains;
I hope they cannot find me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: If you go further;
So good, and free society we hold ye,
We'll jog along too.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Are ye so valiant lady?

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: And we'll be merry, sir, and laugh.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: It may be
We'll go by sea.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Why 'tis the the only voyage;
I love a sea voyage, and a blustering tempest;
And let all split.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: This is a dainty damosel:
I think 'twill tame ye: can ye ride post?

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: 'Oh excellently: I am never weary that way:
A hundred mile a day is nothing with me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll travel under ground: do you hear (Sweet lady?)
I find it will be dangerous for a woman.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: No danger, sir, I warrant; I love to be under.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I see she will abuse me all the world over:
But say we pass through Germany, and drink hard?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: We'll learn to drink and swagger too.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: She'll beat me.
Lady, I'll live at home.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And I'll live with thee;
And we'll keep house together.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll keep hounds first;
And those I have tied heartily.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: I go for Turkey,
And so it may be up into Persia.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: We cannot know to much, I'll travel with ye.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: And you'll abuse me?

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Like enough.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: 'Tis dainty.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I will live in a bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I dare come to ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Say, I am disposed to hang myself?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: There I'll leave ye:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am glad I know how to avoid ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: May I speak yet?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: She beckons to ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Lady, I could wish, I knew to recompense,
Even with the service of my life, those pains,
And those high favours you have thrown upon me;
Till I be more desertful in your eye;
And till my duty shall make known I honour ye:
Noblest of women, do me but this favour,
To accept this back again, as a poor testimony.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I must have you too with 'em; else the will,
That says they must rest with ye, is infringed, sir,
Which pardon me, I dare not do.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Take me then;
And take me with the truest love.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: 'Tis certain,
My brother loved ye dear, and I ought
As dear to preserve that love. But, sir;
Though I were willing; these are but your ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Mir,
sp.l: As I have life, I speak my soul.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I like ye.
But how you can like me, without I have testimony,
A stranger to ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'll marry ye immediately.
A fair state, I dare promise ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yet she'll cozen thee.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Would some fair gentlemen durst promise for ye.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: By all that's goodEnter la. Gastre nauntoler, Lugier, and De-gard.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: And we'll make up the rest, lady.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Then Oriana takes ye; nay, she has caught ye;
If ye start now let all the world cry shame on ye:
I have out travelled ye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Did not I say she would cheat thee?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I thank ye, I am pleased, ye have deceived me;
And willingly I swallow it, and joy in't;
And yet perhaps I know ye: whose plot was this?

sp.speaker: Lug.
sp.l: He is not ashamed that cast it: he that executed
Followed your father's will.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What a world's this, nothing but craft, and cozenage?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Who begun, sir.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well; I do take thee upon mere compassion;
And I do think, I shall love thee. As a testimony,
I'll burn my book, and turn a new leaf over.
But these fine clothes you shall wear still.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I obey you, sir, in all.

sp.speaker: Nant.
sp.l: And how! How, daughters! What say you to these gentlemen?
What say ye, gentlemen, to the girls?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: By my troth â€” if she can love me.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: â€” How long?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Nay, if once ye love.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: Then take me,
And take your chance.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Most willingly, ye are mine, lady:
And if I use ye not, that ye may love me.

sp.speaker: Lil.
sp.l: A match y' faith.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Why now ye travel with me.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: How that thing stands?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It will, if ye urge it.
'Bless your five wits.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Nay, prithee stay, I'll have thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You must ask me leave first.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Wilt thou use me kindly;
And beat me but once a week?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: If ye deserve no more.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And wilt thou get me with child?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dost thou ask me seriously?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes indeed do I.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, I will get thee with child: come presently,
And 't be but in revenge, I'll do thee that courtesy.
Well, if thou wilt fear God, and me; have at thee.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I'll love ye, and I'll honour ye:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I am pleased then.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This wild-goose-chase is done, we have won of both sides.
Brother, your love: and now to church of all hands;
Let's lose no time.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Our travelling, lay by.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No more for Italy; for the Low-countries.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
